bestBHT.bht: The crowds were seeking a sign, just as the people of Nineveh had received a sign through Jonah's preaching. Jesus states that his own preaching should have been enough of a sign, but this generation will be given the greater sign of his resurrection. Luke's account is shorter than Matthew's, but both emphasize the crowd's eagerness for a sign. Jesus warns that this is an evil and adulterous generation that seeks signs beyond what has already been given.

Henry Alford: Here we have one part of the sign of Jonas brought out, which is not touched on in Matthew, viz. his preaching after his resurrection to the Ninevites, announcing—for that would necessarily be involved in that preaching—the wonderful judgment of God in bringing him there
thus making his own deliverance, that he might preach to them, a sign to that people; which sign (ver. 32) they received, and repented
but more than Jonas, a greater sign by far, this generation shall reject.
Marvin Vincent: Were gathered thick together [επαθροιζομενων]. The present participle; and therefore, as Rev., were gathering together unto him, or upon him [επι]. Only here in New Testament.
Philip Schaff: Luke 11:29. When the multitudes, etc. Possibly in expectation of the ‘sign;’ but the controversy with the Pharisees was a prolonged one, which would attract an increasing crowd.
Archibald T. Robertson: Vivid picture of the crowds around Jesus."
The preaching of Jesus ought to have been sign enough as in the case of Jonah, but the resurrection will be given."
Luke's report is much briefer and omits what is in Matthew 12:41.
John Gill: This is an evil generation... an adulterous one."
They seek a sign... and there shall no sign be given it."
But the sign of Jonah the prophet; one like unto it.
John Wesley: It seeketh — The original word implies seeking more, or over and above what one has already.

bhtAttempts.bht: The crowds gathered around Jesus eagerly seeking a sign, just as the people of Nineveh received the sign of Jonah. However, Jesus declares that the preaching of the Word should have been sign enough, but this generation will be given the greater sign of His resurrection. Luke's account is briefer, omitting details found in Matthew's Gospel. The crowd was growing as the controversy with the Pharisees continued, and Jesus warns that this evil and adulterous generation seeks signs beyond what is already given.

The crowds gathered around Jesus seeking a sign, just as the people of Nineveh received the sign of Jonah. However, Jesus declares that the preaching of the Word should have been sign enough, but this generation will be given the greater sign of His resurrection. Luke's account is briefer, omitting details found in Matthew's Gospel. The crowd grew as the controversy with the Pharisees continued. Jesus warns that this adulterous generation seeks signs beyond what is already given.

The crowds gathered, expecting a sign, just like the Ninevites had received the sign of Jonah. Jesus, however, declares that the preaching of the Word should have been sufficient. He reveals that this generation will be given an even greater sign through His resurrection. While Luke's account is shorter, it captures the vivid image of the crowds surrounding Jesus. This evil and adulterous generation is seeking more signs, despite the sign already given.

The crowds were thickly gathered around Jesus, seeking a sign similar to the one Jonah had given to the Ninevites. However, Jesus reveals that His preaching should have been a sufficient sign in itself. Yet, this evil and adulterous generation desires even more signs. Jesus warns that no sign will be given but the sign of His own resurrection, which will surpass Jonah's sign. Luke's account is not as detailed as Matthew's, but it conveys the powerful image of the crowd surrounding Jesus.

The crowds were seeking a sign, just as the people of Nineveh had received a sign through Jonah's preaching. Jesus states that his own preaching should have been enough of a sign, but this generation will be given the greater sign of his resurrection. Luke's account is shorter than Matthew's, but both emphasize the crowd's eagerness for a sign. Jesus warns that this is an evil and adulterous generation that seeks signs beyond what has already been given.
